description.plain:
Blake Tollison Shelton was born June 18, 1976, in Ada, Oklahoma to Richard (used car salesman) and Dorothy Shelton (beauty salon owner). He had a brother, Richie who was killed in an auto accident.  The 6'5" country music singer/songwriter/TV personality has been married and divorced twice.  First to Kaynette “Katt” Williams.  The pair married on November 17, 2003, in the Smoky Mountains and divorced in 2006.  Blake married country music star Miranda Lambert on May 14, 2011, and they split in 2015.

Blake was in two or three pageants starting when he was six or seven years old.  He sang “Cat Scratch Fever” by Ted Nugent and “Old Time Rock
‘n Roll” by Bob Seger.

songs.full_title: God's Country by Blake Shelton
songs.title: God’s Country

description.plain:
From the bell tolling to Shelton’s soulful vocals, “God’s Country” is a tribute to one’s homeland – for Shelton, this is Oklahoma.

The creation of God’s Country was swift, with co-writer HARDY stating, “It was our first write of the year, on January 7, 2019. We wrote it that day, and Jordan did the demo that day. […] They [Blake’s team] cut the song within a week of us writing it. For it to go from not existing on January 1 to on the radio and already in the Top 40 by April…it’s crazy.”

songs.full_title: Nobody But You by Blake Shelton (Ft. Gwen Stefani)
songs.title: Nobody But You

description.plain:
“Nobody but You” is a song recorded by American singer Blake Shelton for his compilation album Fully Loaded: God’s Country. The song features guest vocals from Gwen Stefani, marking the third collaboration between the two artists following “Go Ahead and Break My Heart” (2016) and “You Make It Feel Like Christmas” (2017).

Lyrically, the song describes a relationship between and couple and the love and admiration they share for each other.

songs.full_title: Turnin' Me On by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Turnin’ Me On

description.plain:
“Turnin' Me On” is the only song in Texoma Shore co-written by Blake Shelton. It received an early digital release on November 1, 2017, two days before the album came out.

In an interview with Froggy 99.9, Shelton explained the songwriting process for the song and confirmed it is about his girlfriend, singer Gwen Stefani:

We were playing in Louisiana. I got to the gig, and I was sitting on the bus, and all of a sudden, I started playing this little lick on the guitar, and I came up with this chorus, “Turnin' Me On.” And I thought it was good enough, that it scared me. So I stopped working on the song, and I texted Jessi Alexander, and I said hey, I need your help, I think I got something here that’s pretty cool and I’m gonna screw it up. And she and Josh Osborne helped … basically, they wrote the song. I just had the chorus, but they wrote the song, and they even ended up making the chorus a little bit better. But, I just thought it was a cool song. I was literally thinking of my girlfriend when I wrote this thing. I don’t write that many very personal songs, but this one, I think, hits the mark.

songs.full_title: She's Got a Way With Words by Blake Shelton
songs.title: She’s Got a Way With Words
songs.title_with_featured: She's Got a Way With Words

description.plain:
This angry and sarcastic song finds Blake Shelton singing with venom about a bad relationship breakdown. Shelton didn’t write the tune; it was penned by Andy Albert, Marc Beeson and Wyatt Earp, but its lyrics about breaking up with a woman who’d wronged him got people talking in the wake of the singer’s divorce from Miranda Lambert. Many wondered if this was a grenade aimed at his ex.

Jake Owen was also offered the song, as he was going through a marital breakdown around the same time as Blake Shelton.
“You’d be so surprised,” Owen told Taste of Country.

When I was going through my divorce everybody – every songwriter, everyone – was sending me songs that were like that. That new song Blake Shelton has out, ‘She’s Got a Way With Words’? That was pitched to me and I remember vividly the first time I heard that, I was like, ‘That’s a really good, cool song, very well written. But if I record this song and I’m taken literally – I don’t want my ex to perceive I did that to her.’

Andy Albert, Marc Beeson and Wyatt Earp put together most of the lyrics by just throwing jokes and phrases at each other, many of which ultimately ended up going into the song. “We’re just laughing over them for two or three hours, and then we started to arrange the different lines and put them together in a way that we thought made some sense,” Albert told Taste of Country.

Shortly after hearing the song, Shelton indicated that he wanted to cut it. He put the tune on hold in the early part of 2015, months before he and Lambert announced their divorce. “Then, unfortunately, he went through all of his personal stuff, the divorce and all of that, and I think the song sort of rang true to him in all that was going on in his life,” Albert said. “I feel like that’s one of the reasons why it made it all the way to the end [of the recording process].”

songs.full_title: Minimum Wage by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Minimum Wage

description.plain:
With strong vocals and powerful guitars, “Minimum Wage” is a song describing how the love of a partner is priceless.

Upon it’s live release on December 31, 2020, it was met with some backlash for what critics perceived as insensitive lyrics, given the financial and economic circumstances throughout the pandemic and Shelton’s high net worth.

Shelton later addressed critics and explained his intention behind the song:

“I struggled for so long to get by. But at the end of the day, I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Those days when the big struggle was, ‘Man, do I pay my rent or my electric bill, or do I just say screw it and go buy some beer?’ You had to decide because you didn’t have enough to go around. […] It’s literally a love song about how if times are tight and you ain’t got much money – as long as you have love and you’re happy – at the end of the day, that’s all any of us can really hope for. You got it if you got that. That’s all that matters.”

The song was released on September 8, 2017, with its music video coming out that same day. The video depicts Shelton and his band as a wedding band performing at an elderly couple’s nuptials.

songs.full_title: Austin by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Austin

description.plain:
The song tells the story of a woman trying to get in touch with a long lost love. She calls his phone and hears his answering machine, a message that acknowledges her by the name “Austin,” the town she moved to after their breakup.

This song was the first single Blake Shelton released. During episode 26 of season 7 of “The Voice”, Blake revealed that the whole experience was very overwhelming, and he was actually very nervous when he found out this would be his first single going to radio. “Austin” went on to be a big hit, and was not only Blake’s first single, but his first number one hit. “You never know where a song is going to come from and how it will affect the rest of your life,” Shelton said on The Voice. Turns out, this song launched his career and was the first of many number one singles to come.

description.plain:
In “Sangria,” Blake Shelton recounts a night of passion fueled by sweet Spanish wine.

The songwriters Josh Osborne, J.T. Harding, and Trevor Rosen had a certain place in mind.

We were both picturing those bars in Mexico that are on the beach.
– Josh Osborne

The song marks the second collaboration between Shelton and Adkins, their first being 2009’s “Hillbilly Bone”.

songs.full_title: Came Here to Forget by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Came Here to Forget

description.plain:
One of the deep songs which Blake writes about his ex, Miranda Lambert and how he is trying to get to move on with his new lady Gwen Stefani.
According to the Inquisitr.com this is Blake’s first song after the breakup which is something he has hardly done before.

These are Blake’s words on the song.

I’ve had a lot of music over the years, but I don’t think I’ve ever had a song before that’s such a direct look into my life,” confessed Blake. “That’s why I’m so excited about this particular song.”

Interestingly while this is a happy moment for Blake and Gwen, Gwen made a song too dedicated to her new beau titled Make Me Like You.

songs.title_with_featured: Sure Be Cool If You Did

description.plain:
There’s a noticeable hip hop feel to this chart-topper. The hand claps and high-hat are reminiscent of popular hip-hop drum machines.

It follows a couple who hook up at a bar and then… maybe hook up in bed.

One in ten marriages start with the couple talking at a bar. But one in three marriages start with the couple talking online.

songs.full_title: Lonely Tonight by Blake Shelton (Ft. Ashley Monroe)
songs.title: Lonely Tonight

description.plain:
Blake Shelton and Ashley Monroe sing duet on a song about ex-lovers reuniting for just for one more night.

Official Video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G91KZ56mNbw

“Lonely Tonight” was written by country music singer Brent Anderson and songwriter Ryan Hurd – who’s also penned tunes for Rascal Flatts, Tim McGraw, and Jake Owen.

The song appeared on Shelton’s 2014 Bringing Back The Sunshine album, debuting at number 38 on the Billboard Country Airplay chart for the week ending November 29, 2014.

songs.full_title: Doin' What She Likes by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Doin’ What She Likes

description.plain:
Though it wasn’t written by Blake Shelton himself, the performance makes you believe it was meant for his wife Miranda Lambert. He sings about all the things his woman loves for him to do. Check out the music video if you’re looking for a good laugh!

Even though this track didn’t climb the Billboard charts as high as his previous works (such as “Honey Bee”), it still is a great song that Blake’s voice makes memorable.

songs.full_title: I Found Someone by Blake Shelton
songs.title: I Found Someone

description.plain:
“I Found Someone” is a bonus track on the album “Based on a True Story…”

The song is about a phone call between two ex’s who went through a presumably-difficult breakup and are talking to each other for the first time after a long period of silence.

In the conversation, the two are cordial to each other, and are catching up. At the end of the conversation, one mentions that, it’s been tough at times, but they have found someone new. But there’s no hard feeling and the ex will still hold a place in their heart.

songs.full_title: The Baby by Blake Shelton
songs.title: The Baby

description.plain:
In “The Baby,” Blake describes the relationship between a mother and her youngest child. It’s based on the life of country singer Michael White, who co-wrote the song with Harley Allen.

Shelton told CMT: “‘The Baby’ teaches me, and hopefully everyone who hears the song, not to take your family for granted.”

songs.full_title: At the House by Blake Shelton
songs.title: At the House

description.plain:
“At the House” was the second song from Texoma Shore to be released (after its lead single, “I’ll Name the Dogs”), having an early digital release on October 30, 2017, four days before the album came out.

In an interview with The Country Source, Shelton said of the song:

“At the House” is, I think, part of the reason I decided to name the album Texoma Shore. I was spending a lot of time this past summer out on Lake Texoma. There was one week in particular where it was just Gwen and I out there just basically hanging out. We finally had some time off, so we went out on the water every day, went back up to the house every night and just had one of the greatest times of my life. We were listening to this song and relating to it and realizing, “Man, this is one of those summers that we’re always going to remember.”

songs.full_title: Neon Light by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Neon Light

description.plain:
In a departure from his mostly love struck work of late (“Sure Be Cool If You Did”, “Mine Would Be You”, “Doin' What She Likes”) Blake Shelton performs a song about sweet post break-up revenge.

In this tune, Blake sings about how he uses the bitter end of a bad relationship to fuel his successful music career, by literally writing songs about the breakup. Certain parts of the song can be misinterpreted as a song purely about drinking away the pain, but it’s really a clever double entendre. What he’s referencing is that not only is he he going to perform the acts listed to get over his ex-lover, but then he’s going to write a song about the drinking, write a song about sleeping with someone new, etc. and use these songs to propel his career forward.

It charted at number 63 on the US Billboard Hot Country Songs chart in November 2011. A music video for Shelton’s version of the song, directed by Shaun Silva, premiered in October 2011.

Nashville-based songwriter Craig Wiseman co-wrote this track with Blake in mind. Wiseman’s written songs for Roy Orbison, Dolly Parton, Tim McGraw, and Faith Hill and had 24 number one hits.

songs.full_title: Every Goodbye by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Every Goodbye

description.plain:
Flowing in from the song Came Here To Forget, Blake shines his  hope on this song concerning his new relationship with Gwen Stefani hoping that after the pain of an ugly breakup with Miranda Lambert will be nullified with Gwen’s fresh injected energy into his life.
Sadly Gwen was also at the moment reeling from a 13 year old marriage which she just broke up on grounds of alleged cheating.

songs.full_title: Do You Remember by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Do You Remember

description.plain: Producer Scott Hendricks was adamant that Shelton should record this Michael Dulaney, Will Gray and Ian Kirkpatrick (a friend of the RG family) penned tune, but initially the Country star didn’t get it. Blake recalled to Roughstock: “He sent to me with different singers, guitar/vocals, full demos, a guy singing it, a girl singing it, just because he knew that it was a special song that I just couldn’t get into it for the longest time. And then one day I was back home in Oklahoma and I put in a disc of songs that he sent me and there the damn thing was again. It was like, ‘What has he done!?’ Next thing you know I was singing along! I was like, ‘Man, he’s right! This is a great song!’ And I called him and I said, ‘Let’s cut, 'Do You Remember’ and he sent back, ‘This is the greatest day ever! Yeah!’ And just shows you, I mean Scott, he knows what he’s doing, he knows the great song and it also shows that he’s learned how to work me.”

songs.full_title: Body Language by Blake Shelton (Ft. The Swon Brothers)
songs.title: Body Language

description.plain:
The album’s title track was co-written by former The Voice contestants and Team Blake members The Swon Brothers, who are also featured on the song. The Swon Brothers finished third during the The Voice’s fourth season, and went on to earn a Top 15 hit with the song “Later On.”

“We somehow wrote the title track for this new album and y’all are gonna hear our voices with the man himself!!!” The Swon Brothers shared on social media.

songs.full_title: Over by Blake Shelton
songs.title: Over

description.plain:
“Over” debuted at number 53 on the U.S. Billboard Hot Country Songs chart for the week of May 19, 2012.

Shelton didn’t need another single when he recorded “Over"—he had two albums in the can and the singles already picked out. In fact, he waited a year to put "Over” on the album Red River Blue.
